content.title: Pediatric Vascular Surgery Overview
content.definition: Vascular surgical conditions and techniques unique to the pediatric population, encompassing congenital anomalies, iatrogenic injuries, and acquired conditions requiring age-specific considerations.

key_concepts.description: Small vessel size, vessel growth potential, different tissue characteristics. Vessel diameter may be <3mm in neonates.
Anastomoses must allow for vessel growth. Avoid circumferential grafts when possible. Patch angioplasty preferred.
Developmental hemostasis - different coagulation factor levels. Dosing differs from adults. TEG/ROTEM may be helpful.

congenital.types: Arteriovenous, venous, lymphatic, capillary per ISSVA classification
congenital.management: Multidisciplinary - IR, plastic surgery, vascular surgery

congenital.relevance: Vascular surgeons may be consulted for complex recoarctation or associated aneurysms

congenital.types: Double aortic arch, right arch with aberrant subclavian

congenital.description: Segmental narrowing of abdominal aorta with renal/visceral artery stenosis

acquired.common_causes: Cardiac catheterization, ECMO cannulation, central line placement

acquired.description: Large vessel vasculitis presenting in childhood
acquired.management: Medical therapy first, surgery for complications

acquired.considerations: High incidence of vasospasm, observation period recommended before exploration

vessel_repair.patch_angioplasty: Allows for growth, autologous vein preferred
vessel_repair.bypass: Autogenous conduit (GSV, internal jugular) preferred over prosthetic
vessel_repair.avoid: Circumferential prosthetic grafts in growing children

suture_technique.interrupted_vs_running: Interrupted or growth-factor stitches in small children to allow expansion

outcomes.growth: Vessels and repairs can grow with child if technique appropriate
outcomes.long_term_follow_up: Essential - surveillance for aneurysm, stenosis, limb length discrepancy

learning_objectives: List common pediatric vascular conditions requiring surgical management
Explain anatomical and physiological differences affecting pediatric vascular surgery
Describe surgical techniques that allow for vessel growth
Discuss long-term follow-up requirements for pediatric vascular patients
clinical_pearls: Think growth - avoid circumferential prosthetic grafts
Magnification is essential for small vessels
